comment._content: What a man! Wonder what he did in WW II. Account of the exploits that won him the Victoria Cross. His medals on display at the Canadian War Museum.

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: The Wikipedia article records him as born 29th June 1891 in the Marylebone area of London. However, while the dob may be correct, his birth was actually registered in the Wandsworth District in the July to September 1891 quarter, and on the 1901 census he is recorded as born Herne Hill, Surrey !. On that census, the 9 year old Benjamin was recorded at 131 Palace Road, Lambeth, living in the household of his widowed mother, Blandinah E, (aged 55 and from Islington, London, shown as Living on Own Means). Her other children living with her are:- Arthur B..........aged 22....born Portman Square, London....Student Ethel M...........aged 18....born Portman Square...Student, Kindergarten College, Stockwell Grace S...........aged 11....born Portman Square Herbert M.........aged 19....born Portman Square...Student Stanley...........aged 21....born Portman Square...Government Clerk, Somerset House Winifred M........aged 26....born North Audley Street, London The battalions war diaries have been transcribed and are on-line. On the 17th April the Royal Rngineers had blown a mine under the German Positions on Hill 60 and the 1st Battalion were pushed forward to assist with holding the newly won ground. 12th - 19th April 1915 qrrarchive.websds.net/PDF/ESD0011915003.pdf 20th April 1915 qrrarchive.websds.net/PDF/ESD0011915004.pdf 21st - 22nd April 1915 qrrarchive.websds.net/PDF/ESD0011915005.pdf "Lieutenant" Geary gets a mention on the 8th March 1915 as being on an officer patrol at night in no mans land qrrarchive.websds.net/PDF/ES00119150302.pdf

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Benjamin Handley Geary was buried in St Mark's Cemetery, Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, Canada www.findagrave.com
